FL State Atty McCabe's new filing is the first instance of a FL state law enforcement official weighing in on # DFS, @ WALLACHLEGAL points out
From FL State Attorney's # DFS filing: "It appears that the state of Florida is the real party in interest in this case."
Florida filing: State Atty Bernie McCabe is "in support of Plaintiff's motion for remand." Plaintiff is FL citizen Nelson Steiner.
Now, FL State Atty McCabe is supporting Steiner's lawsuit. Wants court to force DraftKings and FanDuel to give back their FL profits.

Nelson Steiner, former "baron of the Tampa Bay mobile home industry," sued DraftKings and FanDuel in November:http://www.tampabay.com/news/business/pinellas-lawsuit-alleges-draftkings-fanduel-are-illegal-gambling-sites/2253549 …
More bad news for DraftKings and FanDuel out of Florida: State Attorney Bernie McCabe is backing Florida civilian Nelson Steiner's lawsuit

You can see that the power analysis doesn't go far enough: people have been making it for centuries, but Stalin or Trump always comes back.
The psychodynamic phase of demonizing our fathers, or the Nuclear Nobodaddy at the heart of The Establishment is but a passing phase.
We know these lessons from psychotherapy: it's the passage through darkness that brings us to the light. There is no other way.
But there is a way out of the trap through the *bottom* - through places that nobody will go because nobody wants the responsibility burden.
At least it will work a hell of a lot better than half-assed scams, dreams of a mass awakening into peace, love and light. It's not coming.
I think a "viral disillusionment" where disgust and self-loathing for populating a world with nuclear bombs and starving orphans will work.
Because, actually, if you stop it becomes clear a lot of things are very, very wrong. "Mass Awakening" could be up... or it could be down.
Sometimes I think my job is to hammer a spike into the sheet ice that covers the western mind. One day I will hear it crack, and we'll fall.

@ olivierjanss I can't get the necessary 10GB/s or so of bandwidth anonymously, is it acceptable that I can't mine anonymously?
@ olivierjanss @ BitFuryGroup It's cheap to do the right thing and have more than two or three pools; larger blocks makes that more expensive.
@ olivierjanss @ BitFuryGroup Right now overhead costs are quite low; setting up new pools is relatively easy.
@ olivierjanss So, you're OK with basically two or three people being able to revert +6 deep confirmations? What cost do you assign to that?
@ olivierjanss So, suppose we end up with 10GB blocks and only two or three big pools that cooperate with each other, is that acceptable?
@ olivierjanss We're in a position where a hacker could easily reorg 6+ deep confirms by hacking a handful of computers.
@ olivierjanss What do you think we should accommodate?
@ olivierjanss The fact that two or three mining pools can at minimum 51% attack the network temporarily right now is big problem.
@ olivierjanss That money is a linear effect as mining hardware becomes commoditfied; not much of a centralising effect long term.
@ olivierjanss The centralising effect is that high overheads effect big mining operations' profits less than smaller ones.
@ olivierjanss That's inherently centralising due to the economies of scale; nodes/tx bandwidth is a fixed overhead cost. Want low overhead.
@ olivierjanss So we can centralise, change the protocol, or accept that Bitcoin has a limited tx capacity. What tradeoffs do you make?
@ olivierjanss Unlimited transactions are impossible in a decentralised Bitcoin - you have to verify all other txs in the current protocol.
